If anyone's looking for an update, the best place seems to be the WHO website on their "Malaria vaccine implementation programme." Strong statistics will still take more time, but it seems to be looking good so far. From their article, "Increasing equity to malaria prevention through vaccination pilot in Malawi":

"So far, accrued safety data are very reassuring.

The pilot is progressing well, community acceptance of the vaccine is strong, and the programme is now on track for a review of RTS,S data and a potential WHO vaccine recommendation for wider use in sub-Saharan Africa as early as October 2021."

Happy World Malaria Day! (April 25th)

Two vaccines I'm waiting for are malaria and lyme. Lyme disease vaccines exist for humans and pets, and work well in pets, but cause arthritis in humans. Lyme disease shots for humans are no longer produced and I live in a spot where deer and deer ticks are overpopulated, with the ratio of infected deer ticks to non-infected deer ticks is over 4x higher than average. Malaria is super rare where I live, but it still exists and I am unlucky enough to have O-type blood (a favourite blood type for mosquitoes) and live in a swamp (which is where mosquitoes come from).

I often wonder why you confer an almost deistic reverence to scientists in the presentation of Sci-Show videos.  One example from this video: "the low effectiveness was a disappointment to many scientists when it was first published".  It seems like you're suggesting non-scientists were ambivalent.  I agree that science - as a research discipline - takes a level of abuse from conspiracy theorists, religions, politicians and those journalists who feed them than some other lines of work (eg. nursing, fire-fighting, refuse recycling and factory work).  But on the other hand, it does sometimes seem a little patronising; a little divisive in the sense that a lot of people are more-or-less excluded from your definition who have much to do with the process (eg. teachers, medical practitioners, airlines pilots, engineers, beta-testers and science communicators like yourselves, just to take a few disparate examples).  I can see some motivation in your approach, but on the other hand I think that taken to excess it has a potential to divide more than unite; and that's why I'm interested to hear your rationale.

There was a time when malaria was a problem in some parts of the US. On the west coast, malaria went all the way to Seattle. It was a problem in southern British Columbia. It was not a major issue lie in equatorial regions but it did exist. There were many pathogens that out ranked the malaria parasite. Cholera was a big killer there.
Now, dig this cheery news. With global warming, the malaria zone is moving north and will enter the USA again. Maybe that will inspire pharmaceutical companies.
Of course, that issue will be larger in Europe, as the climate warms, given its proximity to Africa.
Some believe that the Sahara might be an effective barrier but there are many reasons to doubt that.
It is not just because the mosquitoes move north as the climate changes. There is also the problems created by international human travel. Someone recently returned from Africa or some parts of Asia carrying the parasite could infect the mosquitoes in the area. The mosquitoes do not produce the disease, they pick up the parasite when drinking the blood of an infected animal, including humans.

A 40% effectiveness rate for the vaccine? What do you mean that's disappointing? According to the World Health Organization in 2015 (https://www.who.int/features/factfiles/malaria/en/) "roughly 212 million malaria cases" occured throughout the world. With an "estimated 429 000" deaths caused by malaria.

Now let's break down the numbers, that is up to 171,600 deaths prevented. That's a big number, yes, but is it worth the cost? Well it's interesting because I am not nearly as concerned about preventing as many deaths, as I am about preventing undue suffering. If you have ever studied Malaria in it's various forms, it is miserable. It is a painful, degenerative condition, akin to torture.


212 million people had malaria in 2015 approximately... That means if you live in the United States (in 2015) the amount of people that caught malaria worldwide, is equal to about 2 out of every 3 people in the U.S.A.


This 40% vaccine drops that number down to an estimated 127.2 million cases, a rate of less than 2 out of every 5 people you know.


Basically I am absolutely amazed that this vaccine now exists, I am thrilled for the effectiveness it shows, and the effect it will have on countless humans.


While 40% may not be perfect, it gives us a real fighting chance, and we should continue to support further research however we can in my opinion.


Thank you for bringing us this information SciShow.

I am skeptical about this vaccine. First of all people become more resilient or immune after exposure. Won’t the vaccines affect this process, since the immune system doesn’t get exposed to this ? Such that when a person encounters a phenotypically different strain ,they experience stronger symptoms.
Secondly , there are numerous highly effective cures for malaria available on the market . The problem in poor countries is access (physical and financial) to these medications. Even though it might help fight 40% of certain kinds of plasmodium, after 4 total shots, majority(60%) of those infected will still experience full blown malaria which will be treated by conventional medication. Why should governments spend millions inoculating children against treatable diseases when it would be better off distributing treated mosquito nets and creating access to medication. I’m not against vaccination in anyway. I’m just highly skeptical of this sub par solution providing a false sense of security, taking away money that would be better spent implementing other more effective preventative measures that stop exposure. Seems like the pharma corps want to recoup losses made after years of flushing money down the drain on this low quality solution. The pilot programs are in highly corrupt countries where the leaders are easily influenced to allow these kinds of programs which we know is only effective against a very narrow section of the plasmodium phenotypes in the wild. As Hank said, Scientists we’re disappointed, but the drug companies are hella excited. Should smell fishy to you too

Ok. THIS is epic.

Even at 40% this could potentially knock the hell out of malaria. The parasite needs to be taken up by a mosquito from an infected host. Even if 60% of the time (probably lower because not all infected hosts will get bit again while infectious) the parasite is able to complete its life cycle, this will dramatically reduce the number of mosquitoes that are carrying the parasite in the first place. There is no selective advantage to the mosquito (that I'm aware of) for it to carry the parasite. A non infected mosquito should be able to carry on their genes at essentially the same success rate as an infected one.
